tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Possible meanings are 1) "song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration" or 2) "song people sang while going up the steps into the temple" or 3) "song whose words are like steps." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:120:001|120:1]]

tn.ref: If Yahweh had not been on our side ... then they would have swallowed us up alive
tn.text: This is a hypothetical statement that describes a result that did not happen, because Yahweh was actually on their side.  AT: "Yahweh was on our side ... so they were not able to swallow us up alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: If Yahweh had not been on our side ... if it had not been Yahweh who was on our side
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. AT: "Without Yahweh's help ... without Yahweh's help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This metaphor describes how the Israelites could have died to how a fierce animal would attack a smaller animal to eat. AT: "killed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "their anger" refers to the enemies who were angry. AT: "they were very angry with us!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
In these two verses the author compares the enemies of Israel to a flood of water.

tn.ref: The water would have swept us away ... would have drowned us
tn.text: This continues the hypothetical statement from the previous verse. It describes a result that did not happen, because Yahweh was actually on their side.  AT: "The water did not sweep us away ... did not drown us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: The water ... the torrent ... the raging waters
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: swept us away ... overwhelmed us ... drowned us
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: The water would have swept us away
tn.text: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water. AT: "Our enemies would have easily defeated us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the torrent would have overwhelmed us
tn.text: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water that would have drowned the Israelites. AT: "our enemies would have overwhelmed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the raging waters would have drowned us
tn.text: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a raging river that would have drowned the Israelites. AT: "our enemies would have destroyed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The enemies are spoken of as if they were wild animals that would destroy the Israelites by eating them. AT: "destroyed as if we were eaten by wild animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: escaped like a bird out of the snare of the fowlers
tn.text: The writer describes his escape from the enemies as if he was a bird that had escaped from the snare of the hunters. AT: "escaped from our enemies as a bird escapes from the trap that hunters have set" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a small trap of string or wire made for catching small animals or birds
The plot of the enemies to catch the writer failed as if it was a snare that had broken. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
